description: From classical Latin animadvers-, past participial stem of animadvertere (“animadvert”) +‎ -ive. Compare post-classical Latin animadversīvus.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Having the ability to perceive; percipient.

examples: The disgraceful conduct of the Returning Officer for the City of London Election has been the subject of animadversive conversation in our own particular circle.
